qas.question: When air enters both the oral and nasal cavities, where does it flow through?
Increasing pressure on the diaphragm thus increasing air output more frequently is usually caused by?
A result of air being sucked into or blown out of the lung thats moving its pressure gradient is referred to?
Where did the term Bellows Lung come from?
When mammals take oxygen into their relaxed diaphragm, what happens to the abdominal wall?
What is the ribcage able to passively recoil?
What does contraction of the thorax do while increasing the volume of the lung cavity?
When air enters the nasal cavity, what does the rib cage expand?

context: Breathing is largely driven by the muscular diaphragm, which divides the thorax from the abdominal cavity, forming a dome with its convexity towards the thorax. Contraction of the diaphragm <b7_0>flattens the dome<b7_0/>, increasing the volume of the cavity in which the lung is enclosed. Air enters through the oral and nasal cavities; it flows through the <a0_0>larynx, trachea and bronchi<a0_0/> and expands <b8_0>the alveoli<b8_0/>. Relaxation of the diaphragm has the opposite effect, passively recoiling during normal breathing. During <a1_0>exercise<a1_0/>, the abdominal wall contracts, increasing visceral pressure on the diaphragm, thus forcing the air out more quickly and forcefully. The rib cage itself also is able to expand and contract <b6_0>the thoracic cavity<b6_0/> to some degree, through the action of other respiratory and accessory respiratory muscles. As a result, air is sucked into or expelled out of the lungs, always moving down its pressure gradient. This type of lung is known as a <a2_0>bellows lung<a2_0/> as it <b5_0>resembles a <a3_0>blacksmith's bellows<b5_0/><a3_0/>. Mammals take oxygen into their lungs, and <b4_0>discard carbon dioxide<b4_0/>.
